additionalTextInformation.text:
See the following for further references to the subject, although the present painting is not mentioned: Volker Westphal, Zum Gemälde des Lucas Cranach d. Ä.: Christus segnet die Kinder, in: Weltkunst XLI, 1971 (1. March), p. 226, fig. s. 181. The painting described exhibits the same composition as the present painting, showing Christ with his arm stretched down to the left, while he turns towards the woman bending down on his right. Whereas the Christ figure depicted in the other type bends his right arm to the right and touches a second child with his hand. The woman at the right in the foreground shown from the reverse belongs to this second type. Kunsthalle Hamburg (Koller-Auction May 1977, No. 5079).
[Maria Winner/Sarah Klein, Augsburg, 21. Nov. 2016]

pageContext.description:
Christ stands at the centre of this rectangular composition, shifted slightly to the left of the central axis and surrounded by a crowd of mothers with their children. He holds one of the children in his arms and has placed his hand over another's stomach. The mothers crowd in on him from either side. The apostles are visible in the top left corner and their defensive stance betrays their scepticism.
[Görres, cda 2017]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
Reverse: worm channels 
Paint layers: fine cracquelée, the paint layers are abraded in the the green robe of the bearded man at the left edge, the varnish has a matte appearance in the green dress of the woman to the right of Christ and there are some retouches along the joint and the shoulder of the child in Christ's arm. The ground is visible in the head of the man at the right edge. Isolated scratches and smal damages in the paint layers.

tests.text:
Panel: lime (?); consists of four horizontally aligned planks; probably trimmed on three sides: the painted edge has only been preserved on the right edge 
Reverse: cradled, thinned, no plane marks

New frame from the end of the 19th or beginning of the 20th century, probably fitted when the panel was cradled
wood: oak, bare wooden profiles with metal ornamentation

The surface of the painting is smooth, the paint was generally applied in numerous layers - a slightly impastois evident in sections. Material: egg tempera. The difference in quality between the flesh paint and the draperies is striking.

pageContext.signature:
Artist's insignia bottom right: winged serpent, but in style not typical for Cranach workshop
[Kunstsammlungen und Museen der Stadt Augsburg, revised 2016]
